requirements: Reproduce the paper "Challenges in Training PINNs: A Loss Landscape Perspective"

sub_tasks.requirements: The experiments described in section 2.2 have been run
The convection problem domain experiments described in section 2.2. have been run
An MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented
The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that it can have 3 hidden layers, each of equal width
The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that the width of its hidden layers can be set to 50, 100, 200 or 400. All hidden layers have the same width.
The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that there can be a tanh activation function between each hidden layer

The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that the MLP's weights can be initialized using Xavier normal initialization, i.e. $W \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \frac{2}{\text{fan\_in} + \text{fan\_out}}) $ where $fan\_in$ = number of input units for the layer and $fan\_out$ = number of output units for the layer. The biases are initialized as 0.
Code has been implemented such than an MLP can be trained for solving the Convection problem

The loss function used for training the MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that it corresponds to the "non-linear least squares problem" described in section 2.1, with the relevant differential operator and boundary/initial condition operators outlined in Appendix A.1
Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, training can be run for 41000 training iterations per seed.

Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, the final L2RE can be measured and is properly implemented as outlined in section 2.2 with the relevant ground truth analytical solution outlined in Appendix A.1
Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, 5 random seeds of training can be run
Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, the final loss can be measured

Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, at each iteration the MLP can be trained on a fixed set of 10000 residual points randomly sampled from a 255 x100 grid on the interior of the problem domain, 257 equally spaced points for each initial condition and 101 equally spaced points for each boundary condition. The sampling is done once, before training begins, and the sampled points are kept fixed throughout training. Domain, boundaries and initial conditions should match Appendix A.1
MLPs of various widths have been trained with the Adam optimizer at various learning rates to solve the Convection problem
Code has been implemented such that to train an MLP to solve the Convection problem, Adam can be used as the optimizer

Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer, the learning rate of the Adam optimizer can be set to 1E-5, 1E-4, 1E-3, 1E-2, or 1E-1
Code has been executed such that a three-hidden-layer MLP has been trained to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer across various network widths and learning rates
Code has been executed such that a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 has been trained to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer across various learning rates
Code has been executed such that a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 has been trained to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1E-5

Code has been executed such that a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 has been trained to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1E-5, and the final loss and L2RE have been measured

Code has been executed such that when training a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1E-5, 5 random seeds were trained

Code has been executed such that when training a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1E-5, it was trained for 41000 training iterations per random seed.

Code has been executed such that when training a three-hidden-layer MLP with a layer width of 50 to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1E-5, at each iteration the MLP is trained on a fixed set of 10000 residual points randomly sampled from a 255x100 grid on the interior of the problem domain, 257 equally spaced points for each initial condition and 101 equally spaced points for each boundary condition. The sampling is done once, before training begins, and the sampled points are kept fixed throughout training. Domain, boundaries and initial conditions should match Appendix A.1

The wave problem domain experiments described in section 2.2. have been run
An MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented
The MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented such that it has exactly 3 hidden layers, each of equal width
The MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented such that the width of its hidden layers can be set to 50, 100, 200 or 400. All hidden layers have the same width.
The MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented such that there is a tanh activation function between each hidden layer

The MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented such that the MLP's weights are initialized using Xavier normal initialization, i.e. $W \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \frac{2}{\text{fan\_in} + \text{fan\_out}}) $ where $fan\_in$ = number of input units for the layer and $fan\_out$ = number of output units for the layer. The biases are initialized as 0.
Code has been implemented such than an MLP can be trained for solving the wave problem

The loss function used for training the MLP for solving the wave problem has been implemented such that it corresponds to the "non-linear least squares problem" described in section 2.1, with the relevant differential operator and boundary/initial condition operators outlined in Appendix A.3

The final loss metrics recorded at the end the executed training sweep described in section 2.2 show that, when selecting the learning-rate configurations with the lowest loss for a given optimizer-width combination, across most network widths and problem domains, Adam+L-BFGS always achieves the lowest minimum loss compared to just using Adam or L-BFGS as the optimizer. Minimum loss is defined as described in the caption of Figure 8.

The final L2RE metrics recorded at the end the executed training sweep described in section 2.2 show that, when selecting the learning-rate configurations with the lowest minimum L2RE for a given optimizer-width-problem-domain combination, across most network widths and problem domains, Adam+L-BFGS always achieves the lowest minimum L2RE compared to just using Adam or L-BFGS as the optimizer. Minimum L2RE is defined as described in the caption of Figure 8.
